CreditLine: Acquired by Henry Walters with the Massarenti Collection, 1902
Description: Fresh flowers in all their fragile, transient beauty and variety were not available in the winter nor could specimens be preserved, as could those of animals, so flower paintings, drawings, or colored prints were especially treasured by collectors. The flamboyant sweep of the composition and emphasis on blossoms that are full to slightly past their prime mark this flower piece as from the second half of the 17th century when the baroque style touched even flower painting. The motif on the vase of putti (chubby todlers, more knowing and worldly than their apparent age would suggest) adds a classicizing tone to the floral display that reflects the expansing influence of French tastes throughout Europe. This is a rare signed piece by the daughter of Jan Peeters I, who worked in Antwerp and painted Southern Seaport in a Storm (Walters 37.1921). Only her birth date is known.

Exhibitions.Textblock: World of Wonder. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1971-1972.
Salute to Belgium. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1980.

MuseumLocation.DisplayCurrentLocation: Charles Street: Second Floor: Chamber of Wonders

Provenance: Don Marcello Massarenti Collection, Rome [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1902, by purchase; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Vase of Flowers
